content.body: Yeah I would

content.body: only if it's all-or-nothing
DS was my initial response on the discussion on this side but the feedback is that it just *feels* cumbersome
making one stack per resource is kinda annoying
though I guess not really any different than the wrapper, in practice
Maybe, but it works.
More context from the discussion I've been having on this side. It should give more context
Changing ownership should be rare.
Keeping in mind that this is coming from someone who is super familiar with RAII patterns and move semantics in C++
yeah but it takes one more line than my little wrapper, because you have to `new` the stack before you can use it
content.formatted_body: yeah but it takes one more line than my little wrapper, because you have to new the stack before you can use it

content.body: difference between two lines of boilerplate and one line of boilerplate is a lot!
anyway yes it totally works, just saying that if this was bothering someone a lot I would recommend they write a wrapper such as the above and maybe that will placate them
Except your wrapper could just new up a `DisposableStack`. It also breaks the RAII pattern, since you need a 2nd `const { resource: foo } = ...` line.
content.formatted_body: Except your wrapper could just new up a DisposableStack. It also breaks the RAII pattern, since you need a 2nd const { resource: foo } = ... line.

content.body: implementation of the wrapper is not important, just the ergonomics, and if it were me I would definitely be happier breaking the RAII pattern and having one line of boilerplate per resource, vs having two lines of boilerplate

content.formatted_body:
const movableFoo = new DisposableStack();
const foo = movableFoo.use(makeDisposable());

is just as many lines

m.new_content.formatted_body:
using movableFoo = new DisposableStack();
const foo = movableFoo.use(makeDisposable());

is just as many lines

content.body: Sure; I guess I wasn't thinking of the `const { resource: foo } = movableFoo;` as boilerplate.
content.formatted_body: Sure; I guess I wasn't thinking of the const { resource: foo } = movableFoo; as boilerplate.

content.body: Looking through the HTML spec, I see a lot of cases where load/error and fired async with JS causes; media resize is async and can be caused by e.g. changing the track; various media events (abort, emptied, timeupdate, and many others) are an async result of load(); input elements' showPicker() can async-fire cancel/input/change; el.select() can async-fire various select events, dialog.show() async-fires a toggle event
This isn't an event, but toBlob() invokes its callback async
At one point we'd discussed having "queue a [...] task to" carry an implicit "propagating the current context" - I'm not sure I ever heard a reason why that wasn't viable.
